Comments_List: I know this class was unusual in the sense that Edgar is teaching it while FES finds a new professor, and I respect his effort in overhauling it. But I still don't think it contains very useful information and certainly does not uphold FES's mission of preparing us to be practitioners. Learning energy conversions was useful but overall the class consists of looking at graphs at how the majority of the world uses fossil fuels, emissions are rising, and climate change is happening - basically all things you know before coming to FES. This may be a good class for someone who knows nothing about energy but is probably worth skipping.
Nothing that couldn't have been discovered using an online unit converter and wikipedia.
how to critically look at he energy system
I learned energy conversions, different energy systems, a lot of good topics, but as I mentioned in the other survey it did feel a little disjointed at time.

This was a crash course in energy systems analysis. I thought the class was very well designed to give student with and without a strong quantitative background a good overview of energy systems, different technologies, and the strengths and weaknesses of those technologies.

This was a crash course in energy systems analysis. I thought the class was very well designed to give student with and without a strong quantitative background a good overview of energy systems, different technologies, and the strengths and weaknesses of those technologies.
Fluency in the language of energy and an understanding of the systems around it.
Learned about energy basics (thermodynamics), energy technology.
This course helped me to get more comfortable with energy equations and understanding energy flows
Energy concepts

Quantifying energy in various forms
Energy conversions
Building physics and energy and buildings
Importance of life cycle assessments in relation to energy production, consumption and by-products
Renewable energy pros and cons
Trade-offs of the decarbonisation / low carbon development pathways
I gained knowledge in the areas of energy sources, supplies, conversions, services, and the role of energy in climate change scenarios into the future.

Energy's role in the economy, environment, and society. Energy conversions and calculating efficiencies. Methodologies for energy analysis. How various energy technologies work, and their pros/cons. Energy implications for mitigating climate change.
Developed and enriched understanding of fundamentals of energy, energy flows, and energy systems. We grappled with challenges of improving and modernizing energy systems.
This course provided some background on current approaches to decarbonizing our energy system, as well as student presentations on specific technologies that may help us achieve this goal.
Did not meet my expectations at all. There should be a survey on what students would find helpful to learn.
see previous answer

I heard that this was a "must take energy course" and on the whole it did not disappoint. Lectures were interesting, the technology brief was great, and I felt like Edgar was passionate about the class. On the less good side, it did feel like a ton of topics so taking away some of the key concepts was a little challenging by the end of the semester.

I thought the course aligned very well with my expectations. I thought Professor Hertwich did a good job balancing the quantitative and qualitative components of energy systems and appreciated the amount of guest lecturers that we had who were truly experts in the specific technology we were discussing.

I thought the course aligned very well with my expectations. I thought Professor Hertwich did a good job balancing the quantitative and qualitative components of energy systems and appreciated the amount of guest lecturers that we had who were truly experts in the specific technology we were discussing.
Quite well.
Well.
Moderately well. I thought the first half of the course was well thought out and rigorous, but I'm not sure I learned much in the second half
sort of well
Great - the curriculum was comprehensive in terms of the physical, natural and some socio-economic aspects of energy systems.

The knowledge and skills gained aligned well with my expectations as I anticipates receiving a general overview of energy systems and services. I would say that the course provided a basic understanding of all things energy.

They aligned pretty well. The course ended up feeling less intensive/time-consuming/difficult than I had anticipated (based on information from students in last year's course), likely because it was taught by an interim professor this year.

Generally, they aligned quite well. I was surprised at how quickly the course diverged from strictly covering energy systems to low-carbon systems in relation to climate change, land use, etc. I don't think this was necessarily a bad thing, but I think a bit more focus on energy fundamentals would have been warranted, while zero-carbon/within 2-degrees energy (& economy & land) systems could have been a whole class unto itself.
I had hoped that we would talk more about the quantitative (that is, engineering and economic) aspects of energy systems, but aside from a lot of unit conversions, we didn't really do much math.

Have a professor who cares, have TAs who care. Real, timely feedback, problems sets that are well written with clear expectations that don't use a confusing, non-intuitive template. 

Really it's unacceptable to have an energy foundations course so carelessly taught here given high student interest in energy and its importance in climate change policy.

As mentioned above, I think finding a full time lecture (or Edgar continuing to do it) is vital. The course needs to be developed and needs sometime to be refined. The strengths are its a great topic, an important time for it, and very interesting. The materials themselves were alright and the course seemingly improved from last year, but just to address some of the disjointedness of the second half of the course.

I thought the general format of the course was well thought out and enjoyed the student technical briefs during the second half of the semester. The one weakness that I thought the class had was in the formatting of the homework. While I thought the content on the homework was fine, I thought the way that the homework was formatted was confusing and did not help me reinforce the material that we had learned in class as well as it could have. I think it would have been much better if we had been able to use paper and pencil to submit our homework instead of using excel. I think it would have reinforced what calculations we were doing and when and would have been less time consuming than using the designed template.

Better slides, different problem sets
Really interesting lectures. The homework was not especially well written, or at least I did not like the answer templates.
PLEASE hire dedicated ESA professor
We went over some important concepts very quickly. I also wished we'd gone over exercises in class.

Strengths:
Great curriculum for the subject.
Knowledgeable professor and TAs.
Grateful that the course was not overly US-centric - most of the energy-oriented courses I've shopped tend to have this issue. Professor made an effort to present examples that covered both US and non-US regions.

Weaknesses:
The classroom: the ratio of size to student numbers. Avoid Burke if at all possible for a class size that could be accommodated in a smaller venue. Very easy to disengage in that type of environment.

The strengths of this class are the wide coverage of energy topics, guest lecturers, and insights in the areas of life cycle analysis and advances in energy technologies. The weaknesses include the lack of depth on certain topics because the topics were so varied and the problem sets relying upon skills not gained from the course itself. There were certain problem sets that relied upon information not found in the textbook, lectures, or outside reading. The course could be improved by establishing a clearer link between the reading and the lecture and problem sets. In addition, the tech briefs were a helpful exercise in presenting on the subject matter learned, but perhaps more problem sets in the second half of the class would have resulted in greater overall student learning.

I really enjoyed the portions of the course that focused on the application or implications of energy in systems.  For example, I really enjoyed the lectures that covered the lifecycle analysis of energy technologies, and compared them to one another based on the type of lifecycle methodology. I also enjoyed the discussion comparing/contrasting bioenergy carbon emissions from fossil-fuel carbon emissions. 

I struggled with portions of the class that dove deep into the weeds on technical engineering or scientific concepts. For example, the lecture on the Decarbonization Index was difficult for me to follow and understand. 

I thought some of the questions on problem sets, as well as the Midterm and Final exams, were not entirely well thought-out, causing confusion among students in how to best answer what was being asked.

I also enjoyed working on the technology briefs in the second half of the semester, but felt the assignment could have provided a little more detail regarding the scope, depth, format, etc.

I was very satisfied with this course! The course could have been improved by a bit more focus. I felt like the lectures included many diagrams with empirical results, such as various types of Sankey diagrams, but the key takeaways from such figures were not always clear. Particularly in the second half of the semester, the consensus of the class seemed to be that students did not know what concepts to study for the final. Especially troubling to me were final study questions that included facts like typical efficiencies of different steps of the energy system or emissions per vehicle-km of different elements of the life cycle, which focused much more on facts than on concepts. Given that these types of questions are 1) statistics that can be looked up and 2) empirically developed, probably sensitive to methodology, and likely constantly in flux, I would have liked more focus on how to analyze, interpret, and make decisions using such statistics rather than on regurgitating the numbers.

Since the grading seemed a bit subjective, it would be nice to receive clearer feedback on assignments--I often felt that I thoroughly understood the material but this was not reflected in my grade. I also didn't find the technology briefs particularly helpful but am not sure how to improve them other than perhaps eliminating entirely.
Skip.
Be glad you get a real energy professor in the future.

This is a good overview of energy systems and current and future energy technologies. The course is designed for students with little to some quantitative background in energy systems and would be beneficial to anyone who is looking to work in energy.

This is a good overview of energy systems and current and future energy technologies. The course is designed for students with little to some quantitative background in energy systems and would be beneficial to anyone who is looking to work in energy.
Really interesting class, not a huge workload. You will learn high level information, you will not gain analysis skills.
not relevant since we are hiring a new professor

A great introductory class for students not necessarily comfortable or initiated in energy topics. Some level of comfort with Math, Chemistry and Physics required, but a number of these things can be assuaged with online learning videos. The Physical Sciences foundation course and AMES course provided a great foundation for some of the data-oriented tasks for this class.
Take the time to refresh your understanding of thermodynamics, energy conversions, and microsoft excel as these will all be critical toward understanding and completing the problem sets and exams.

Students looking to specialize in Energy & the Environment should definitely take the course. It offers some important foundational concepts for the sector. I do not think it would be the most worthwhile course to take if you aren't planning to have an energy focus at FES.
Very important to gain the fundamentals of energy! Take this class!
